dialogues.speaker: FATHER TIGER
dialogues.text: Any change?

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER TIGER
dialogues.text: Hmm... well, let me see. She sarcastically holds the crying baby to her ear.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER TIGER
dialogues.text: He’s still crying.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER TIGER
dialogues.text: Well can’t you do something?

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER TIGER
dialogues.text: Can't you?

dialogues.speaker: FATHER TIGER
dialogues.text: (menacing) I don’t think you’d like my idea. Suddenly the baby quiets, as if he understood the threat.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: A-hem. The tigers look up. Sitting in a tree overhead is JEFFERS a chimpanzee.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: Sorry to interrupt. I couldn’t help overhearing.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER TIGER
dialogues.text: Funny how eavesdropping can lead to that. Jefferson climbs down and sits with them.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: As a concerned fellow prisoner, I can’t help but point out the obvious.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER TIGER
dialogues.text: Obvious what? @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You two were born in the wild. He’s first-generation captivity. Your instincts don’t apply here. Not behind bars.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER TIGER
dialogues.text: Would you excuse us? This is a family matter.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: But it’s also a larger, society matter.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER TIGER
dialogues.text: What do you suggest we do?

dialogues.speaker: FATHER TIGER
dialogues.text: Jefferson doesn’t have suggestions. Only complaints.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: They're observations. Much needed observations, I might add. And I can’t possibly fix our situation alone. It will take the combined effort of all the animals to gain our freedom.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER TIGER
dialogues.text: Ridiculous.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: Can't you see? Being locked in these cages is robbing us of not just our dignity, but our very being. The fact that you can’t bond with your son is the perfect example -- The Father Tiger ROARS in anger, causing the baby to star crying again. Jefferson freezes in fear.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER TIGER
dialogues.text: We’re not an example of anything - especially your political nonsense. Now leave us alone.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER TIGER
dialogues.text: (to baby) There, there. Everything’s alright. Jefferson climbs back up the tree, still frightened, but truly sorry that he didn’t help. @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jefferson walking, concerned. Down from a nearby tree com ROSS, a fast-talking, female babboon.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: Hey - how'd it go? Did you help? Did they listen? Are they going to join the fight for freedom?

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: Badly. No. No. And no.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: Don’t give up. It’s a long fight. You said so yourself.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: Thanks, Ross.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: Can I help? How can I help? Jefferson perks up a bit, and stares ahead with convictio

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: Rally in the square. Ross’ face lights up.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: You mean it?

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: You bet I do. He walks ahead. Still smiling, she heads the other way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ross passes a RHINO, a GAZELLE and a FLAMINGO hanging out a closed-up souvenir cart. Without stopping, she tells th

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: Rally in the square. They roll their eyes, but after a moment, they follow her MONTAGE: Ross spreading the word to several different ani that there’s going to be a:

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: Rally in the square. @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055 They all react with the same annoyed boredom, but comply

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sectioned-off, mini ampitheater used for kids’ shows. As thirty or so animals lazily file in, Ross directs the seating as if handling a riot.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: Okay, easy does it. No shoving. There’s plenty of room for everyone. Smaller animals down to the front. Larger folks to the back, please. Working with Ross is FRANKLIN, a slacker, teenage spider monkey. He mimics Ross, pointing animals in whatever direction she has already established for them. When a pair of bats appear at the entrance, Ross immediat pays special attention to them.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: (to bats) Right this way, sir. Miss. -- or is it Mrs.? Ms. probably. You look like a Ms. (to others) Excuse us. Visually challenged guests coming through. Make way, please. (to bats) You’1l be down in front here. (to others) Excuse us. Pardon us. Make way for the visually challenged. Unable to get by the rhino, Ross snaps at him.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: Hey, a little respect here, huh? When everyone is in place, Jefferson ascends the stage. H has pages of notes in his hand and seems confident -- -- Until he looks out at the moderately-sized crowd.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: Umm... uuhhh... tonight (gulp) I just wanted to, um.... @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  The crowd groans. They saw this coming. Jefferson starts sweating.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: No, wait. I just. it’s just... what we need is ...um, ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From the side, Ross desperately roots for him, trying to him the courage to succeed. Franklin stands beside her, m confused than anything.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: There’s this .... um... You see... (defeated) Sorry. Thanks for coming. Jefferson slinks off the stage and sits on a nearby bench The animals file out shaking their heads. CLOSE ON: The Rhino.

dialogues.speaker: RHINO
dialogues.text: (sarcastic) Gee, didn’t see that coming. CLOSE ON: two GIRAFFES filing out.

dialogues.speaker: GIRAFFE 1
dialogues.text: Tell me again why we do this.

dialogues.speaker: GIRAFFE 2
dialogues.text: Because if we don’t come as a group, he’ll come to each of our cages and talk for hours. Ross runs to Jefferson who sits quietly staring ahead. Franklin follows close behind her.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: You did good! That was real... progress, I thought. (to Franklin) Didn't he do good, Franklin?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Kinda the same as last time. And the time before that. And the -- Ross smacks the back of his head with her tail.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: (to Jefferson) It’s not your fault. It’s a disorder called groupatalkaphobia. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  ROSS (cont'd) Instead of blaming the victim, we, as a society, should get you the help you need. She holds his shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We will get through this, and everyone will join the cause. Franklin looks around their setting.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: You think everyone would fit in here? Jefferson starts to hyperventilate at the thought.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: Nice going. Quick! Get a paper bag! Franklin darts off. Jefferson is trying to say something.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: It’s going to be fine. You don’t need him. I’m here. It’s okay. Franklin returns with a popcorn bag. Ross gives it to Jefferson, who sucks air from it and starts CHOKING. Ross pulls the bag away and POPCORN FLIES everywhere. She glares at Franklin.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: An empty bag, you nitwit! Ross does the Heimlich on Jefferson by wrapping her tail around his waist and grabbing it with one hand. It works. Jefferson coughs up popcorn kernels and breathe again. But his eyes stay staring ahead, almost catatonic.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Why don’t we just find his brother?

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: Because no one knows where he is.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Don’t you think that’s weird? Disappearing for two hours every night. @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. But that’s Lincoln. He’s weird. We’1ll just have to wait for him to come back from ... wherever.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Just like last time...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quiet and dark. FRANKLIN (CONT’D - O.S.) -.. and the time before that. And the time before that. We track along a perimeter fence. SUSPENSEFUL MUSIC slowl builds as we approach an unknown building and track INTO exhaust vent in the exterior wall. INT. AIR VENTS —- CONTINUOUS Continuing track as music builds. Faint voices can be hea in the distance, coming from somewhere in the building an traveling through the vents. Their volume steadily increa

dialogues.speaker: GOOD GUY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You'll never get away with this.

dialogues.speaker: BAD GUY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: We'll see about that. We hear the rumbling of a fight as we turn a corner. A spooky blue glow flickers throughout this 15-feet of ai vent. The light comes from a grate at the end of the tunn Sitting in front of the grate, his back to us, is another chimp, Jefferson’s brother LINCOLN. TRACK IN over Lincoln’s shoulder and we see what he sees:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The only light in the room comes from a 20-inch TV in one corner. A lazy, film-geek GUARD (early 20s) sits in the d chair, intently watching a 1970s cop movie. He is unaware of Lincoln, who is also transfixed by the f

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055 The two men have finished their fight. The Bad Guy has t Good Guy pinned to a wall.

dialogues.speaker: GOOD GUY
dialogues.text: The police know about your scheme. They’re on their way right now.

dialogues.speaker: BAD GUY
dialogues.text: I got news for you... CLOSE ON: Lincoln, watching.

dialogues.speaker: BAD GUY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: «+. the police work for me. Lincoln’s eyes go wide, surprised by the revelation. BAD GUY (CONT’D) And your friends won't be bothering me any more. I’ve seen to that.

dialogues.speaker: GOOD GUY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You .... animal! Taken from the moment, Lincoln rolls his eyes with a “yea yeah” look, then reacts in inspired awe as we HEAR the Go Guy escape and the forces of good take over.

dialogues.speaker: BAD GUY
dialogues.text: No!! Ahhhgggghhh!!!

dialogues.speaker: GOOD GUY
dialogues.text: That’1l teach you to operate on the wrong side of the law.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still on a satisfied Lincoln, we hear theme music and see scrolling credits reflected in his still-focused eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ross tries to console a still anxiety-ridden Jefferson wh Franklin tosses a rock in the air and tries unsuccessfull bat it with a stick. Lincoln approaches the trio.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: Hi guys. What’s up? @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We had another rally.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: How'd it go?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Same as last time... and the --

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: Alright!

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: Thanks for watching him. I’1l take it from here. Ross reluctantly makes room for Lincoln, who puts his arm around Jefferson, who is visibly calmer with Lincoln ther

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: Good night, Jefferson. See you tomorrow. Jefferson just nods as he and Lincoln walk off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lincoln and Jefferson walking. Jefferson is a bit calmer.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: It’s just nerves. Public speaking just isn’t your thing.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: How can I be a political leader if I can’t face a bunch of friends in a familiar place?

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: I’m not sure a political leader is what’s needed here.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: That's because you’re oblivious to the oppression. They get to their cage. Lincoln takes a key from under a “hide-a-key” fake rock and unlocks the door. @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  10.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No one takes me seriously.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: That’s because you take yourself too seriously. Did you ever think of that?

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: We have an obligation to the animals who aren’t as smart as we are.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: An obligation to do what?

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: To better our situation. You want to spend the rest of your life in this cage? We’re prisoners! And everyone is too blind to see it.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: No one is blind -- (to himself) Well, except the bats. (back to Jefferson) Look. We’re here. We’re fed. We’re taken care of. We have doctors, for crying out loud. Kids love us.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: Their kids.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: There’s nothing we can do about it. All your activism. Do you really think you can achieve equal rights for zoo animals?

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: See how they brainwash you? There shouldn't be any such thing as a zoo animal. We’re just animals. They're responsible for the zoo part.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: So we should -- what?

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: Unite! Rise up! Take our freedom back! @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  11.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: That’s impossible.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: Nothing’s impossible.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: You can’t win.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: So you should only fight if you know you can win?

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: Ummm...Kinda - yeah.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: That’s some life philosophy. Remind me to write that down sometime so I‘1ll never forget it. Disappointed, Jefferson slinks off to a dark corner.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: Jefferson, I --

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: -- good night. Lincoln sighs, knowing this talk is over - for tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beautiful, sunny day. Throngs of people enter the gates Kids run ahead of bag-holding, stroller-pushing parents. Looking out of place in this crowd is ETHAN LATTE. A pale thin artist-poser-type, Ethan is bald, has a goatee and i dressed all in black: turtleneck, sunglasses and blazer - even though it’s obviously hot out. Ethan talks on a cell phone as he walks.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: That’s not going to happen. We’re shooting the scene just as I wrote it. Tell them that Ethan Latte doesn’t compromise his art for anything. -- Look, I’m in the middle of something here. Kind of a blind date. Never mind where. I’1l call you back. @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  12. He flips his phone closed. As the crowd disperses in different directions, we see that Ethan is with an attrac single MOM in her thirties and her 7-year-old DAUGHTER. The daughter runs ahead. Ethan does little to hide his disdain for this outing.

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: All set?

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: Yes, let’s ... zoo.

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: Sorry again about the mix-up. She really is supposed to be with her father today. It’s really nice of you to come along. Ethan takes out a DV camera and checks the gauges.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: Uh-huh. While looking through the lens to test light, Ethan steps something, soiling his expensive, trendy shoes. The leather shoes have distinctive ORANGE TIPS.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: (to himself) Wonderful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ethan and the Mom approach the daughter, who hangs on the fence, trying to engage the chimps.

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: My sister says you make movies. That’s interes--.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: -- Films. I make films. Movies have clichés and car chases. Lincoln hears this exchange, perks up and comes down to s closer to them.

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: I see. And what do your films have? @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  13.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: Meaningful stories. Strong, conflicted characters. Redeeming social commentary. See the difference?

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: Uh ... sure. She is annoyed at his arrogance, but tries to make the be of it, for her daughter’s sake.

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: I used to see lots of movies. All kids’ stuff these days, though.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: Mmm-hmm. I have a film selected in the Moonsong Film Festival. The mom rolls her eyes and sips from a water bottle. Linc listens intently.

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: That’s nice. Is that like a contest or something? Ethan lets out a condescending laugh.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: It’s only the biggest independent film showcase in the world. You get recognized there and you can write your own ticket in Hollywood, baby. In the middle of another water sip, she nearly chokes on Ethan's “baby.” She’s about to lean into him when:

dialogues.speaker: DAUGHTER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Look, mom! He likes me! The daughter is up on the monkey cage railing, leaning ov

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: Honey, don’t climb on that. She scurries ahead and helps her daughter down.

dialogues.speaker: DAUGHTER
dialogues.text: (whispers) That Ethan guy is weird. @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  14.

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: That’s actually one of his better qualities. She turns back to Ethan, who is again talking on his cell phone, and checking himself out in the glass reflection o another section of the monkey area. Lincoln comes up to the glass and mimics an oblivious Eth The mom and daughter laugh. Ethan hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: Can you get a shot of us?

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: A ... shot?

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: Yeah. Take some video of us in front of the monkeys.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: What would be the point of that?

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: To remember what great fun we had at the zoo. Ethan sighs, checks his camera, the sunlight, and. .

dialogues.speaker: MINUTES LATER
dialogues.text: Ethan has set up an elaborate shoot, with barriers to hol patrons back - until he cues them to walk past as extras. Lincoln watches, riveted. The mom and daughter are MORTIF as Ethan calls to them:

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: Again! .... and action! The mom and daughter smile awkwardly and wave at the came

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: Don’t wave! ... Define the moment! Share the moment! Be the moment ... Don’t react! Act!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: During the shooting, Lincoln holds his fingers up and fra the mom and daughter. His composition is better than Etha @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  15.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: (groans) Cut! Must you be so stiff?

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: Okay, look, we should really be getting home.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: I was only trying to say something with the film.

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: You said plenty. Thanks. It’s been areal... treat. I’1l be sure to thank my sister for setting us up. She takes her daughter’s hand. As they walk away, the daughter looks back.

dialogues.speaker: DAUGHTER
dialogues.text: Bye - freak! Ethan erases the footage and turns to leave, but realizes has no idea which way the exit is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tired and sweating, Ethan is still trying to find the exi He sits on a bench, puts his camera down and tries to mak cell phone call. No reception. Frustrated, he gets up quickly, knocking his camera into crocodile pit. It lands, intact, in a bush. MIKEY, the crocodile immediately eyes it. Ethan starts to climb in. MIKEY moves, and Ethan thinks better of it and calls out.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: Excuse me! A little help here! I need to speak with a zoo employee. A small crowd gathers around the yelling Ethan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lincoln is relaxing in a hammock when BRAD, a free-flying bird lands nearby. @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  16.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: What’s all the commotion over there? Did Mikey eat someone?

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Nah. Some guy dropped his video camera in the pit.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: (perks ) Really?

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Yeah. No big --

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: -- Get to Mikey. Quick! Tell him -- Suddenly, a family is at Lincoln's cage, peering in, so h slyly whispers something to Brad, who shrugs and flies of Now watched by the family, Lincoln scratches himself and swings on the hammock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ethan with a portly ZOOKEEPER who takes his job very seriously, gesturing dramatically with his hands as he sp

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: Can’t you just climb down there? Isn't that your job?!

dialogues.speaker: ZOOKEEPER
dialogues.text: Not exactly, sir. But we can lure the croc back inside - there - to create a safe path - here - from which we can retrieve your personal belonging.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: How long will that take?

dialogues.speaker: ZOOKEEPER
dialogues.text: Well, croc manipulation is by no Means an exact science, but I can assure you we will do our best to retrieve your personal belonging. Brad lands on Mikey’s head and whispers something to him. croc looks puzzled at him. Brad just shrugs. Suddenly, the croc moves for the camera. @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  17.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: He’s moving! He’s going to it! Do something!

dialogues.speaker: ZOOKEEPER
dialogues.text: He’s just exhibiting instinctive behavior. Crocs are naturally very curious. An often overlooked fact about the giant reptile.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: He’s going to eat it!

dialogues.speaker: ZOOKEEPER
dialogues.text: (chuckles ) Oh, I doubt that, sir. He’s not like a shark. If it’s not food or food-smelling, he’1ll just -- Suddenly the croc opens its jaws and eats the camera.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOKEEPER
dialogues.text: -- well, hoo-dee-dumpkin. There's somethin’ you don’t see every day. Ethan doesn’t know whether to lash out or weep.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: Your filthy, wretched zoo is going to pay for that.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOKEEPER
dialogues.text: I'm afraid the zoo is not responsible for personal belongings lost, stolen or damaged during your visit. Your admittance ticket is also a contract --

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: Oh, shut up! He storms off, but not necessarily in the right direction he stops and turns back.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: How do I get out of here!?

dialogues.speaker: ZOOKEEPER
dialogues.text: Oh that’s easy. Down to the giraffes, turn right, through the tunnel and around the flamingo garden. If ya see hippos, you've gone too far! @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  18.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: How utterly....easy!

dialogues.speaker: ZOOKEEPER
dialogues.text: Enjoy the rest of your stay, sir. Ethan storms off. Mikey sits motionless in his pit

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mikey still motionless. He hasn’t moved.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Bravo. Lincoln climbs down next to Mikey and holds out his hand.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: Let’s have it. Mikey opens his jaws, revealing the camera, perfectly int Lincoln reaches, but Mikey CLAMPS shut. Lincoln pulls his hand away just in time.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: Was that supposed to be funny? Mikey’s talk is dumb-sounding with the camera in his mout

dialogues.speaker: MIKEY
dialogues.text: What’s in it for me?

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: MIKEY
dialogues.text: Well that’s not good enough. Lincoln sighs and looks around. He expected this to be a short visit.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: What would you like?

dialogues.speaker: MIKEY
dialogues.text: I don’t know. @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  19.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: Haven't you had quite a bit of time to think about it?

dialogues.speaker: MIKEY
dialogues.text: I guess.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: How about some food?

dialogues.speaker: MIKEY
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: Okay. You give me the camera, and I'll see to it that that rock over there has food on it first thing in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: MIKEY
dialogues.text: Stuff I like?

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: Absolutely. Right by that little door over there. How’s eight o'clock? Mikey thinks about it and finally sticks his tongue out, camera sitting on it. Lincoln takes the slimy camera and wipes it off as best he can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lincoln is testing the camera, learning its features, whe Jefferson comes in.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: And just what do you plan on doing with that?

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: Make a movie, write my own ticket to Hollywood and get recognized at the Moonsong Film Festival.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: What? The Moon-who what festival? Lincoln imitates Ethan, but just to amuse himself.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: It’s only the biggest independent film showcase in the world, baby. @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  20.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: When are you going to stop playing and get serious? Lincoln points the camera at his brother.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: Who's playing? C’mon, pout - oh, you're already pouting.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: Very funny.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: Okay, funny. Funny is good. If only we had a banana peel. Jefferson laughs. Lincoln is stunned.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: Was that a laugh?

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: Yes it was. I have it on tape.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: It wasn’t on.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: But I saw it. ... It’s not a crime, you know. Laughing.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: (joking) But don’t let me see it again! This is serious business! I am an arteest!

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: And I'm going to bed. He goes to his corner.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: Fine, be that way. But you’ll never work in this town again!

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: What? @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  21.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: Never mind. Good night. Lincoln fiddles some more with the camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A long line of animals waits to get in. EXT. ZOO SQUARE STAGE —- CONTINUOUS Lincoln points the camera at us, looking out from one sid

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: Okay, this is called a screen test. Opposite him is a FLAMINGO holding a sheet of paper.

dialogues.speaker: FLAMINGO
dialogues.text: You want us to talk?

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: FLAMINGO
dialogues.text: And humans are gonna see this?

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: It’s okay. Animals talk in movies all the time. Just read the lines. The important thing is to relax and have fun. He looks back into the camera. The flamingo opens his mou to speak and Lincoln cuts him off:

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: And remember - you just discovered you have a horrible disease and that your children are actually aliens from outer space. The flamingo’s face goes blank. He looks down at the page then back up at Lincoln.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Whenever you’re ready... The flamingo can only manage a GULP and a GRUNT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  22. We see various zoo animals through Lincoln's camera frame A male rhino:

dialogues.speaker: RHINO
dialogues.text: (deadpan ) You'll never take me alive, coppers.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Good. Try it again, a little tougher. You’re mean. Everyone’s afraid of you.

dialogues.speaker: RHINO
dialogues.text: (identical deadpan) You'll never take me alive, coppers. A female gazelle:

dialogues.speaker: GAZELLE
dialogues.text: I know you don’t lose me anymore.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Love.

dialogues.speaker: GAZELLE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: You don’t love me anymore.

dialogues.speaker: GAZELLE
dialogues.text: I never loved you. We’re not even the same species-- That’s disgust-- oh! The line. Sorry. I get it. A male OTTER stands silent for a beat, then suddenly look scared and points to the sky:

dialogues.speaker: OTTER
dialogues.text: Look out!!!! Lincoln looks up from his camera, and checks his script.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: That was good, but the line is -- BONK! Lincoln gets hit on the head with a falling pine co @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  23.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The tests are done. Lincoln starts packing up and sees Ro watching curiously. She’s conflicted throughout the scene

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: Oh, hey Ross. Didn’t see you there. C’mon down. Thanks for waiting.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: (dreamy ) Me? (catches herself) Oh, no. I’m not here to be part of this movie thing. She moves in closer to Lincoln, unable to hide her fascination with the camera.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: No?

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: I’m here to scold you. Playing with human people toys when they lock -- (points) What does that do?

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: It zooms the picture closer. Wanna see?

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: Of course not! -- okay. Lincoln smiles and lets her try the camera. As she looks through, Ross reaches in front of the camera, trying to t whatever is obviously zoomed in close in her view.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: You were scolding .. .?

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: (still looking) Huh? Right. People toys.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: You don’t have to impress my brother. He likes you. Ross looks up from the camera. @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  24.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: That has nothing to do with -- did he say something? What did he say?

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: He doesn’t have to say anything to me. I know. (beat) I also know he wouldn’t mind if you were in the movie.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: Really? I don’t know. That would be kinda -- okay! -- No, I couldn’t. He'd be mad. . . wouldn’t he?

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: Yeah, probably. (beat) But what if you weren’t actually in the movie? Ross pretends to get it, nodding.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: Aaahhhhhh -- (gives up) What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A compelling aerial shot moves down and tracks left aroun corner of the building as a scared-looking LEOPARD runs b top speed. Some moments later, as the dust settles, an exhausted OSTRICH runs by in pursuit.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Lincoln sitting high on the neck of Ben, the giraffe. The camera is fastened to Ben’s head and his neck is bent low turned, having provided the shot we just saw.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: Cut! That was great! The giraffe slowly straightens his neck, lifting Lincoln above the crowd. He looks down to the ostrich.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: How did that feel? Was that alright? @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (winded) I just don’t think anyone will believe that I could catch him. Murmurs of agreement from the animals.
They only have to believe that you want to catch him. Inspired, admiring approvals resonate. Lincoln is revered

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: Alright everyone. That’s it for tonight. Remember, eight-o’clock tomorrow night. We’1ll be... where are we tomorrow? He turns to Ross, who wears a cap and holds

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: Gift shop.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: a clipboard. Gift shop. Eight o’clock. Get some rest, everyone. Great job tonight. The giraffe puts Lincoln down next to Ross.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: You sure you wanna rip?

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: Stop filming for the night.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: Oh, wrap. It’s wrap. Yeah, I gota «+. thing I gotta do.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: Oh, your ... nightly ... thing.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: Yeah, the thing. I'll see ya tomorrow. Lincoln starts off. @Michaal Maltin / wea #1109055  26.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: Alright then, have fun -- I mean, if it’s a fun thing. Lincoln waves without turning around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lincoln is walking with his camera, elated. He passes a quiet, dark cage and stops. He thinks a moment and goes b

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lincoln enters. No one seems to be around, but he suddenl hears a menacing GRUNT from a dark corner. Looking closer Lincoln sees the glowing eyes of WASHINGTON, a huge, intimidating gorilla.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: Washington? The gorilla GRUNTS again in the darkness.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: Hi. Sorry to disturb you.

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: Then why did you?

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: I'm making a movie, and I need a big tough guy. So I was wonder-- Washington suddenly ROARS and CHARGES at Lincoln, who dro the camera in fear and jumps up a tree.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: Yeeez, man. What’s that all about? We’re on the same team here.

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: No we’re not. Get out of here!

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: I gotta get my camera. Can I get it without you hurting me?

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: I don’t know. Can you? Washington picks up the camera, looks at it, then suddenl holds it up high as if he will smash it on the ground. @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  27.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: Don’t! It’s not mine! It’s borrowed. C’mon. Gimme a break. You don't want to do it, fine. A lot of others do, though. You’ll be ruining it for everyone. Washington puts the camera down, growling some more, then moves back to his dark-corner spot. Lincoln climbs down, picks up the camera and scoots quick to safety. Before leaving, he calls back in:

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: What’s with you, anyway? Silence. Lincoln shakes his head and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lincoln walks on and suddenly Jefferson is in his face.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: Funny thing happened on the way to the rally.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: Nobody showed up. It was me in front of a crowd of zero.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: There’s an easy joke there, but I’m not going to say it.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: Your little movie nonsense with this toy of our captors is setting back the cause. Lincoln is angered by his brother’s selfishness.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: Oh, here we go again. The cause. Freedom for all. So we can walk out into the street and get hit by a bus.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: Getting out of this prison is the only thing that matters. @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  28.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: -- to you.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: You're not helping.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: And you're just jealous because everyone’s more interested in doing what I want them to do.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: They don’t know any better.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: And you do?

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: Yes! Movies are pointless.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: You've never even seen one. Movies have a ... power. They can make you laugh, cry, and think in all kinds of new, exciting ways. They can ... they can change the world.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: Have you been eating bugs off the orangutans again?

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: That was one time.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: How can you honestly think all that make-believe nonsense could possibly matter?

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: They're stories. Everyone has one.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: They're a waste of time. Lincoln thinks. Eureka.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: Prove it.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: What? @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  29.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: Waste some time with me. Right now.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: What? Where? -- (realizes) Is that where you -- ? Figures.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: Come with me. ... C’mon.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: Alright, fine. But only to show you just how stupid movies are.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: Just give it a fair chance.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: Yeah, yeah. They head off together, Lincoln leading the way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lincoln’s movie-watching spot is far more cramped now tha he’s sharing it. Jefferson fidgets mercilessly. The security office below is empty and dark, except for a small desk lamp.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: How can you sit here every night? Where are we? Suddenly the office door opens.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: Shhhhhh.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: (whispers) This is stupid already. Lincoln puts a finger to his lips. He’s serious. The Guard takes a DVD from its case and ceremoniously put in the player. He adeptly works the remote through menus and starts the film. Onscreen we see an office building with a MEGAMULAC sign on top. A narrator speaks in voice-over: @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  30.

dialogues.speaker: NARRARTOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: What you about to see is true. The people involved are not actors. Lincoln sighs in disappointment, but Jefferson is intrigu

dialogues.speaker: NARRARTOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Ten years ago, nine employees of Megamulacorp lost their life savings while company executives got rich. Onscreen image cuts to a group of sad-looking people.

dialogues.speaker: NARRARTOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: These employees fought the system, beat the odds and won their justice. This is their story. Lincoln shakes his head and leans to Jefferson.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: (whispers) This is a documentary. They’re boring. We can come back another ni--

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: Shhhhhh. Lincoln suddenly realizes - of course - this is exactly t kind of movie Jefferson would be into. And into it he is. Riveted. Lincoln tries again to watch.

dialogues.speaker: OLD WOMAN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Worked there all my life. Thought I could trust ‘em. Guess I was wrong. Bored already, Lincoln's eyes wander. He starts inspectin and biting his nails.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jefferson in the same spot, watching. Lincoln lies next t him, fast asleep, drool hanging from his open mouth. As the credits roll, the guard leaves the office. Jeffers discovers the sleeping Lincoln and shakes him.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: Huh? What? Who? I’m ready. -- Oh it’s over...So, what did you think? @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  31. Jefferson has a determined, inspired look.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: Where’s that camera? He starts away down the vent.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: Ha. You see? I told you. Movies can -- wait, my camera? Lincoln follows.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: Why do you want my camera?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The chimps draw their usual crowd. Lincoln and Jefferson in a hammock, concealed by tree foliage. They speak softl mask their conversation from the watchful humans.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: I don’t know. Documentaries are so boring.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: We finally have a chance to tell our story. Really tell it.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: I was telling a story.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: About what?

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: An unlikely hero who saves the world.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: From ... what?

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: (duh) The bad guys.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: Okay. And your hero is...?

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: (proudly ) Featherman! (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  32. LINCOLN (cont'd) (reluctant) Stuart.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: The ostrich? A superhero?

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: Featherman actually has no super powers. He’s just highly trained --

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: -- Stuart?

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: He’s the best actor I could find. He does this thing with his eyebrows. (imitates) It’s really freaky.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: In a documentary, no one would have to act. We’d all be ourselves.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: What about all the work we’ve done? Jefferson fishes for an adequate answer. A-ha!

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: You've made everyone comfortable in front of the camera.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: You mean like practice?

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: Rehearsal. The point is, you were right. Movies can change the world. So let’s change ours. Together.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: Together?

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: Our story. Our movie.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: I get to work the camera?

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: Who else could do it? (beat) Partners? @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  33. Jefferson puts out his hand. Lincoln shakes it.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: Partners.

dialogues.speaker: EXT ZOO GIFT SHOP
dialogues.text: The cast and crew busily set up the shoot in and out of t unlocked, open gift shop. Lincoln and Jefferson arrive to see all the confused, suspicious faces.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: Okay, everyone. A little change in plans. Our movie is . . . canceled. The group groans and looks accusingly to Jefferson, who frantically coaches Lincoln in whispers:

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: Replaced. Improved. Fixed! Put a positive spin on it!

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: (to group) Improved, actually. It’s a new movie. A documentary about life in the zoo. Jefferson's going to help. He knows a lot about this kinda stuff. Ross waves to Jefferson, then coaxes Lincoln into the sho

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: We're already set up here. Are we gonna have to move?

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: Uh, yeah. I guess -- Jefferson has followed them in.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: -- No. The gift shop is fine. Let’s do a scene right here.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: Great! ... What scene? Jefferson picks up a blue, badly made, stuffed kangaroo. @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  34.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: Exploitation. Jefferson walks out. Lincoln nods. As soon as Jefferson i gone, Lincoln stops nodding and turns to Ross.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: What does that mean?

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: People making money selling stuff that looks like us.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: That’s bad?

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: Definitely bad.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: Alright then. Exploration it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A KANGAROO holds the stuffed toy and looks at the camera. Lincoln films while Jefferson observes, off camera.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: Don’t you think blue kangaroos are more fun and exciting?

dialogues.speaker: KANGAROO
dialogues.text: (confused) No.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: Human people do. A crowd of animals has gathered behind Jefferson (and the camera). They are listening, getting steamed up, too.

dialogues.speaker: KANGAROO
dialogues.text: What do they know about kangaroos?

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: Hard to say. They know a lot about merchandise though. What sells and what doesn’t. That sort of thing. The kangaroo gets angry, still holding the doll. @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  35.

dialogues.speaker: KANGAROO
dialogues.text: Nobody asked me.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: Who cares what you think? You live in a cage. That does it. The kangaroo RIPS the head off the doll. Stuffing POOFS out and flies in the air. Before Jefferson can react, the crowd of animals bursts i the shop and begins RANSACKING it. Lincoln runs around and films all he can, while Jefferson desperately tries to stop the chaos.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: No, no. Stop! This is not the point! We can’t do this! Ross tries to help control the situation, while Franklin torn between helping Ross help Jefferson or joining in th mayhem which looks like fun. Finally, Jefferson finds Lincoln as he excitedly tries to catch all he can on tape. They yell over the ruckus.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: This is great!

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: No, it’s not. It’s terrible. We’re just proving we’re the mindless animals they say we are. Lincoln stops the camera and lets that sink in.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: Can you get them to stop? .. . Please?

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: (to the crowd) Cut! Everyone stops in a sudden silence and looks at Lincoln. Jefferson can’t believe his brother’s control.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: This is not the scene we want. To make our point - and it’s a good one - we have to be smart and civilized. For now, take five. @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  36. The animals look to each other, confused, and each begins take what’s left of the merchandise from the shelves.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: Minutes. Take five minutes. Like, a break. Understanding now, they all leave the shop, leaving Linco Jefferson and Ross.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: It’s my fault. I shouldn’t have riled them up like that.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: It’s okay. You couldn’t have known they’d riot. (to Jefferson) It’s good, though. He got through to them. They’re mad.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: We have to be more than just mad. We have to be smart and convincing.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: You need a central story. Something simple and emotional that the audience can relate to. But it has to be an example of the larger point. Something triggers in Jefferson's mind. He lights up.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: (to himself) An example. . . the tigers. (to Lincoln) You're a genius!

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: Thanks. What about the tigers?

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: They're our story. C’mon! Jefferson runs out. Lincoln turns to Ross.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: Could you get everyone back in here, and --

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: -- clean up. I’m on it. @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  37.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: Thanks. Lincoln leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lincoln catches up with Jefferson.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: So what's their story?

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: New baby. First generation captivity.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: And they're having trouble? As if on cue, the baby crying starts from inside the cage

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: Lots. . . The Dad is not going to be cooperative.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: You sure?

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: Pretty sure. EXT. ZOO’S TIGER AREA - CONTINUOUS Jefferson enters. Lincoln follows close behind, already filming. The baby tiger cries throughout.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER TIGER
dialogues.text: What are you doing back --- (notices Lincoln) What is he doing?

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: Don’t get upset. We’re making a movie.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER TIGER
dialogues.text: A what?

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: It’s a documentary about our struggles here. @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  38. The tiger growls.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER TIGER
dialogues.text: Would you like to see struggle?

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: There’s no need to threaten.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: It’s okay. Threats are good. Very dramatic.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: Yeah but, ... I could get hurt. The tiger LUNGES for them and they both shoot up trees.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER TIGER
dialogues.text: I can climb trees, you know.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER TIGER
dialogues.text: But you will not. The three guys look at her, somewhat surprised.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER TIGER
dialogues.text: If there’s a chance this will help, we will cooperate (to her mate) -- fully. (to Jefferson) What do we need to do?

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: Just let us document.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER TIGER
dialogues.text: Document?

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: Film. With the camera.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: Pretend we’re not here. The filming resumes, awkward at first, but soon the paren relax, and Lincoln gets some compelling shots of the cryi baby and the tigers’ efforts to console him. Interview shot of mother tiger.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER TIGER
dialogues.text: Part of the problem is scheduling. All babies need a schedule. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  39. MOTHER TIGER (cont'd) Ours doesn’t always match the zoo’s. And I think that confuses him. Makes him upset. I think. Looking up over the camera, Lincoln gives Jefferson a cov wink. Jefferson nods. All is well when suddenly Lincoln looks at Jefferson agai only this time in a PANIC.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: What? Lincoln slowly hands the camera to Jefferson. Jefferson l through. POV VIEWFINDER: WARNING! LOW BATTERY! flashes onscreen.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: (to tigers) Thanks. That’s all for tonight.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: We'll be back tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: We hope! They quickly climb out. The tigers watch confused. Even t baby stops crying long enough to watch the monkeys go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jefferson and Lincoln swinging home, in silhouette.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Can we fix it?

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: We need more batteries. Or to charge this one.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: How are we going to do that?

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: I have an idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Under background MUSIC, we see Lincoln speaking to Frankl BRAD and three other birds at a YOU ARE HERE directory si @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  40. Lincoln occasionally points to the sign with a stick. Although we can’t hear him, it’s obvious he is relaying a strategic plan. When he finishes, Franklin raises his hand and asks an unheard question. Lincoln reacts with dismay and, by way answer, he slowly points to the big “You Are Here” spot. EXT. VARIOUS ZOO AREAS — DAY Establishing shot: the zoo is packed with loud, excited people. Hiding behind a tree, Franklin puts headphones in his ear and turns on his iPod. CUE MUSIC MONTAGE - Jimi Hendrix: Crosstown Traffic Franklin slips and ducks around the zoo - COMPLETELY UNNOTICED by humans -- and PICKPOCKETS them, taking video camera batteries and accessories from bags and backpacks. He tosses whatever he pilfers up to the birds, who catch items in flight and bring them to ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lincoln sits hidden from view behind rocks. A bird flies in, carrying a camera battery. He lands on a branch above Lincoln and drops the battery. Lincoln catch it and tests it in the camera. It fits. He gives the bird thumbs-up, and the bird flies away. A few moments later another bird flies in carrying a different sized battery. Lincoln checks it, shakes his he and tosses it back to the bird who catches it and flies o

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When the attendant is not looking, Brad appears, places t rejected battery on the counter and flies away. The attendant turns back and is surprised to see the batt She takes it and puts it on a shelf -- alongside SEVERAL OTHER video camera batteries, of all shapes and sizes. @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  41.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lincoln sits behind the rocks checking a battery. It’s go He puts it with several others and signals to the deliver bird by dragging his finger across his neck. They're done

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lincoln works the camera as Jefferson speaks to the Mothe Tiger, who holds the baby in a rare moment of quiet sleep

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER TIGER
dialogues.text: It’s the only life he’1l ever know.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: Captivity?

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER TIGER
dialogues.text: Yes. The father comes into the shot. Calm. Concerned.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: (to him) And how does that make you feel?

dialogues.speaker: FATHER TIGER
dialogues.text: (thinks ) Sad, I guess. Lincoln zooms the shot in close, then CUTS. The brothers to each other with pride, almost disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: I think we got it.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: I think so, too. They nod their thanks to the Mother Tiger and quietly lea

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jefferson by himself reading “Public Speaking for Dummies Ross knocks and Jefferson scrambles to hide the book.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: Hi. @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  42.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: Hi, Ross. C’mon in.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: Where’s Lincoln?

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: Taking care of some business. He’ll be back in a little while.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: Oh, no. I wasn’t coming to see him. He just wasn’t here. Isn’t here.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: So what’s new?

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: (toying) Oh nothing really. Except that we finished filming tonight.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: Oh, that’s nice-- (realizes) You what? You’re done. Congratulations! She hugs him, and they awkwardly de-tangle themselves. Jefferson clears his throat.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: That’s really great. I’m so proud -- we're all so proud.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: Well, we couldn’t have done it without everyone’s help. Especially yours.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: Oh, I didn’t do much.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: Sure you did.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: You’re welcome. @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  43. They share yet another long, awkward moment.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: So where is Lincoln?

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: Taking care of some business.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: Ah.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lincoln sits alone at a worker's cluttered desk, clicking mouse of a computer. The screen shows a website: FLYTIX.C with airplane and ticket logo. He reads and types.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: Destination? Hollywood. Passengers? Two. Credit Card... ? On the wall is a post-it note with a list of work-related numbers. He drags his finger down the list until he finds

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: Travel account. He smiles as he types in the numbers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The square is packed with animals. Behind the “stage” are huge sheet has been hung taut to act as a screen. Franklin hooks the DV camera (red, yellow, white) to the zoo's AV equipment. He seems to know what’s he’s doing. From the side of the stage, Lincoln, Jefferson and Ross w as the place fills to capacity. Jefferson is visibly nerv

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: (to himself) ...Just some opening remarks.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: You don’t have to do this.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: I can do this. @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From the other side of the stage, Franklin turns off the overhead lights, leaving one like a spotlight shining on stage. The crowd murmur dies down to a still silence.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: Maybe you better do this.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: I’m on it. Lincoln bounds on stage like a rock star to enthusiastic applause. We waves, milking the attention.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: I'd like to thank you all for coming to tonight’s premiere of “In the Cage”. This is your movie. Your story. Your hard work, sacrifice and honesty are what brought us here. Wait, there was one other thing. One very important someone whose strength and vision made this movie a reality. He’s a very special animal... He looks to Jefferson.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: .+. And I’m not just saying that because he’s my brother. Let’s give a big hand to the genius behind this movie ... Jefferson! Lincoln leads the clapping and the crowd joins in. Jefferson waves and nods sheepishly from the sidelines wh Ross proudly goes wild next to him. When the applause subside, some JOKER animal in the back calls out:

dialogues.speaker: JOKER ANIMAL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Speech!

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: Alright, that’s not funny. The crowd suppresses a laugh. Jefferson takes it in strid

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: Let's watch the movie, shall we? The light on Lincoln fades and sheet/screen suddenly glow with projected light. @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  45. The movie begins with a series of close-ups of cage bars locks. Jefferson's voice comes in under the picture, a smooth, confident V.O. narrator.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It looks harmless enough from the outside, but don’t be fooled. Life in a zoo is no different than life in prison. Except for one thing. Those in prison, it can be assumed, have committed some crime. The animal audience watches, intrigued. The shot switches Stuart, the ostrich, looking helpless and hopeless.

dialogues.speaker: OSTRICH
dialogues.text: I never did anything wrong. Shots of other animals, looking sad, in their cages.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: So why is it that we are forced to live in these cages, unable to roam free as we are meant to. (dramatic pause) Unable to form the family bonds that are supposed to be so natural. The film cuts to the tiger footage. The audience remains engrossed as they feel for the crying baby tiger.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE WINGS
dialogues.text: Lincoln motions for Jefferson to follow him. While the cr continues to watch, the two brothers quietly duck away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jefferson at the sink. He’s just finished splashing his f and looks up into the mirror. He’s STARTLED to see Lincoln standing behind him, menacin holding up a STRAIGHT RAZOR that flashes in the light.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: Ahhh!!! Holy smokes! What are you-? Lincoln laughs. Jefferson regains his breath.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: Sorry, I’ve always wanted to do that. Here you go, little brother. Time to humanize. @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  46. He hands Jefferson the razor and squirts shaving cream in his own hand.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: You’re sure about this?

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: Of course. He puts shaving cream all over his neck, chin and cheeks, with another razor, expertly removes a section of hair . In a MUSIC MONTAGE, Lincoln and Jefferson shave their who bodies then get dressed in mini-outfits: jeans, trendy striped shirts, sportcoats and hip shoes. They admire themselves in the full-length mirror. Lincoln is completely bald, but Jefferson opted for leavi black hair on top of his head in a mod style.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: Where'd you get all this stuff?

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: I know people.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: (thinks ) No you don’t. Lincoln shrugs and checks his watch.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: We better get back. They head out the door.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: How come you get a watch?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The animal audience still watching the screen. Their sadn has changed to determination. They’re inspired.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Our day of freedom will come. It is what’s right. It is our destiny. Finale music swells, and the crowd bursts into cheers. @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  47. Lincoln and Jefferson arrive back in the wings just in ti They couldn’t be prouder.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: You did it.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: We did it. They shake hands, then yank each other into a brotherly h The animals swarm over to Lincoln and Jefferson, ready to congratulate them, but the whole crowd STOPS DEAD, STUNNE SILENT when they see the shaved, dressed chimps. Ross, in front, GULPS.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: I see you guys had a makeover thing while we, um... a little extreme perhaps, but nice. It could work. (beat) I like the shoes.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: (to everyone) I can explain. We’re glad you liked the movie, and I’m proud to announce that Jefferson and I are leaving - tonight - to take “In the Cage” to the Moonsong Film Festival in Hollywood.

dialogues.speaker: CROWD
dialogues.text: Ooooohhhhh....

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: If we win, uh ... I mean when we win, everyone will see our movie.

dialogues.speaker: CROWD
dialogues.text: Hooray! Relieved, the animals resume their congratulations with b slapping and handshakes. Franklin approaches the brothers with a Polaroid camera.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: You two. Lincoln and Jefferson turn together in a smiling pose. Franklin SNAPS the picture. As it comes out the front he hands it to Lincoln. @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  48.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Folks! Excuse me. If everyone will come this way . . . We can continue this party in style. She leads them to a nearby clearing where a “premiere par has been set up with snack carts and soda machines. On th center table is an ice sculpture of a person in a bathtub The animals pick up the pace, pass Ross and dig in.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INSERT THEATER: Alone, Lincoln puts the movie tape with t camera in a leather bag, which he carries on his shoulder He looks at the developing Polaroid of him and Jefferson. After it comes into view, he puts it in the camera bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jefferson and Ross at the party.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: It really is great.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: So you're leaving?

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: Flight’s first thing in the morning. We gotta be outta here.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: It’s like three days. We’ll be back before you miss us.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: I miss you already. Jefferson is surprised. Ross realizes she said that out l

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: I mean - I just meant... Good luck.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: Thanks. @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I’m just gonna go, you know, whoop it up. 49. She makes the “raise the roof” gesture. Jefferson laughs.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: You're not the whooping type.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: What are you saying?

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: That you don’t whoop.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: I whoop. I can whoop with the best of ‘em.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: Uh-huh, sure.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: Ask Franklin.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: Oh, there’s a reliable source.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: I’m crushed that -- -- Come with us.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: What? Where?

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: To this movie festival thing.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: I couldn’t - could I?

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lincoln and Jefferson, off by themselves.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  50.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: -- Because I only have two plane tickets, that’s why not! Me and you. (calms ) Look, little brother, I’m glad you asked her. That’s a big step. Lincoln looks over Jefferson's shoulder at something.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: It’s okay. She’1ll understand. She’s very ... what’s the word I’m looking for?

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: Packed. Suddenly Ross runs up to them, carrying several packed ba

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: Hi guys! This is so exciting!

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: Yeah ... Ross ... The thing is.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: What? What is the thing? I can’t go. You're saying I can’t go. That's the thing.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: There are only two tickets. One for Lincoln -- Lincoln holds up the tickets. Suddenly a big gorilla hand comes into frame and takes one. Lincoln reacts.

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: -- and one for me.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: Hey! Give that back! Washington inspects the ticket.

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: I'll be joining you on your trip.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: I don’t think so.

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: I wasn’t asking. @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  51.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: Yeah, well as much as I'd enjoy your delightful company, this is our trip. So go back to your cave, Kong. Lincoln tries to snatch the ticket back from Washington, can’t get clear before Washington grabs him by the throat

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: Whoa-whoa! Wait a sec! Let go of him! What’s going on here?

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: (choked) I think he wants a ticket.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: Put him down! Washington drops Lincoln, who lands breathing heavily.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: (to Washington) What’s this about?

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: (seething) I would like... very much... to accompany you to Hollywood.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: Well, you can’t. Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: One ticket for me. One for him. Washington points to Lincoln.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: What about me?

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: You go in here. He reveals a giant duffle bag. WASHINGTON (CONT’D) Avoid the big ...city ... crowds. Jefferson suddenly looks nervous. Lincoln has regained hi breath and pulls Jefferson aside. @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  52.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: Don’t listen to him. He’s just trying to scare you.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: (scared) Maybe he could, you know, protect us.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: And who'd protect us from him?

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: We'd better get going. We don’t want to miss our flight.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: No way. This trip is about the movie. The movie you didn’t want to be a part of.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: He’s right, Washington. I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: (re duffle bag) There’s room for your friend. And all her luggage. Jefferson pauses. He looks at Ross, who tries to hide the fact that she’s suddenly beaming with hope.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: Alright, fine. You win. Hey, everyone! What does an 800-pound gorilla get? Anything he wants. Ha-ha. (to Jefferson and Ross) Get in the bag and let’s go.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS AND FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Ross holds Franklin by the shoulders. He has his headphon in, so Ross talks loudly.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: Now I’ll only be gone a few days. You'll be alright, alright? Franklin nods. @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  53.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: Just stay out of trouble. Practice your skateboarding. I want to see new tricks when I come back, okay? Franklin nods again.

dialogues.speaker: ZOO CLEARING
dialogues.text: The animals wish the group well. Jefferson helps Ross put luggage into the duffle. Then they climb in. The bag look ridiculously heavy, but Washington picks it up with ease. He follows Lincoln, who has walked ahead, fuming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lincoln and Washington arrive. As Lincoln fishes in his j pocket, Washington reaches for the lock as if he will rip off to free them. Lincoln stops him.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: Whoa, whoa, Mighty Joe. Lincoln produces a key from his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: No destruction. See this as the first of many things on this trip we're going to do my way. Got it? Lincoln unlocks the gate and swings it open.

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: Why are you coming anyway? What's in it for you?

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: It’s personal.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: Great - thanks for sharing.

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: You’re welcome. They walk out. @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  54.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At a corner, Lincoln stands alone next to the duffle. He hails a cab. When the cab stops, Lincoln calls in.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: Pop the trunk? The trunk pops open and Lincoln reaches for the enormous But in one fluid motion, Washington appears from behind a tree, grabs the bag, puts it in the trunk, climbs into th trunk himself and closes the hood. Lincoln makes as if he did all that and gets in the backs

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Airport. The cab pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cab idles far from the curbside check-in crowd. Linco and Washington (with the duffle) duck inside the terminal

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lincoln and Washington look around.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: We gotta find you some clothes. But first, gimme your ticket. I’1l do all the talking.

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: You have my ticket.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: No I don’t. You took it. I still have the scar. Lincoln points to his neck.

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: You took it back.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: (panicked) No I didn’t! @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  55.

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: Then Jefferson did. Lincoln is already unzipping the duffle.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: Do you have the other ticket!?

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: (from within) Nope. Lincoln glares at Washington.

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: Somebody took it.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: Yes! You! You took it! From me! And that, not so coincidentally, is when everything started going wrong! Jefferson pokes his head out.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: Calm down. It has to be around here somewhere.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: No, actually, it doesn’t! The truth is, it could be anywhere. Anywhere!

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: EXT ZOO SQUARE —- SIMULTANEOUS Bouncing to his music, Franklin sweeps up after the party unknowingly pushes the missing ticket onto a trash heap.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: You're exaggerating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back to the gang.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: (fake calm) You're right. There are a lot of places where that ticket cannot be. Unfortunately, one of those places seems to be here with us!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  56. Ross pokes her head out of the bag.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: Ahem! Guys. I think the idea is to keep a low profile.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: She's right. Let’s just think of a plan. We can fix this.

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: (to Lincoln) I take the ticket, and you get in the bag.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: No way! You’ve messed up enough already. I’m not having you talking to people and getting us sent... who-knows-where. If anyone’s getting in that bag, it’s you! Lincoln suddenly falls into thought, glancing back and fo between the bag and Washington. Jefferson catches on.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: That's imposs--

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: -- Nothing’s impossible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now carrying the VIDEO CAMERA BAG over his shoulder, Linc stands by himself next to the duffle bag, which is even m stuffed. It looks as though the seams will burst. Lincoln begins walking away, then turns back and snaps hi fingers at the bag. The bag STANDS UP, thanks to Washington’s HANDS AND FEET sticking out holes cut into the bottom. He walks behind Lincoln, revealing all Ross’ luggage which has been left behind to make room.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  57.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lincoln checks the bag. The COUNTER REP looks at the scal and shows surprise. The scale shows FIFTY POUNDS.

dialogues.speaker: COUNTER REP
dialogues.text: Only fifty pounds. Looks much heavier than that.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: I don’t like hotel pillows.

dialogues.speaker: COUNTER REP
dialogues.text: So you bring your own? What a great idea!

dialogues.speaker: REVEAL
dialogues.text: The duffle bag is on the scale, but Washington's foot is sticking out onto the floor, taking all the weight. While the counter rep types, Washington switches feet so can maneuver onto the conveyor belt behind the counter re The scale momentarily shows full weight: 950 pounds. The counter rep stops typing and does a double-take, but scale number suddenly returns to 50. Washington’s other f has reached the floor behind her. The rep shakes it off and easily hoists the bag -- with Washington’s help - onto the conveyor. Lincoln watches anxiously as the oversized bag moves away

dialogues.speaker: COUNTER REP
dialogues.text: Sir? .. . Sir? Lincoln snaps from his trance. She hands him his boarding pass.

dialogues.speaker: COUNTER REP
dialogues.text: Your boarding pass. Gate Seven B. Have a good trip. Sleep well! She smiles at her cleverness, so Lincoln does too. He loo down the conveyor belt again, but the bag is gone.

dialogues.speaker: AIRPORT SECURITY GATE
dialogues.text: Lincoln approaches the gate, the camera bag on his should He watches those before him to see what this is all about @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  58. When it’s his turn, he puts the camera bag on the moving and watches nervously as it goes into the machine. The GU holds a plastic bowl out to Lincoln.

dialogues.speaker: GUARD
dialogues.text: Keys? Loose change? Cell phone? Lincoln just shrugs and shakes his head, so the guard mot him through. Lincoln passes through the gate without any alarm. On the other side, he gets his camera bag, then stops to notice TODDLER being scanned with an electronic wand. Lincoln wa on and we see, waiting for their turn behind the TODDLER, an ELDERLY MAN, a NUN and a fully decorated MILITARY OFFI

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lincoln finds his window seat and settles in, glad that everything is back on plan. He looks out the window and i surprised to see Ross’ luggage by itself out on the runwa

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: (to himself) Hey, isn’t that --? BOOM! The luggage suddenly EXPLODES and security forces r in to inspect. Lincoln winces. Then he sees a runway worker loading luggage onto his pla When he grabs the giant duffle, Washington’s feet come ou the bottom and he “walks” to the conveyor belt. Lincoln smiles.

dialogues.speaker: STACY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Magazine, sir? Lincoln looks up to see STACY, a blond mannequin of a fli attendant, holding magazines.

dialogues.speaker: STACY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We have Global News Today, Science Today, Gourmet Today, Investing Today, Fashion Today and Movie Talk. Lincoln perks up, takes Movie Talk and flips through it.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (in his head) Look at all this glitz and glamour. Hollywood is definitely the life. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  59. LINCOLN (V.O.) (cont'd) And I’m almost there. Whoa, she’s with him? What’s up with that? He comes across a feature on the Moonsong Film Festival.
