dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: Huh. Moonsong. It’s a sign. Let’s see what it says... (reading to himself) Once a year, Hollywood's elite gathers in the mountainside town of Rockbluff, Colorado for a three-day event showcasing the year’s best independent movies. Lincoln sighs, closes his eyes dreamily and lays his head back. After a moment or two of bliss... His eyes POP OPEN in PANIC. He looks back down at the magazine, then stands up on his seat.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: Rockbluff, Colorado?! Stacy, the flight attendant swoops over to him.

dialogues.speaker: STACY
dialogues.text: Sir, I'll have to ask you to take your seat and remain calm.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: I’m on the wrong plane! I thought I was going to Hollywood.

dialogues.speaker: STACY
dialogues.text: It’s okay. There’s no airport in Hollywood. This is a Los Angeles flight. You can --

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: -- No - I’m supposed to go to Rockbluff, Colorado! I gotta get off! Don’t shut that door! Passengers are freaking out at the strange dwarf causing scene. TRACY, another plastic-perfect attendant comes by.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: What’s the trouble?

dialogues.speaker: STACY
dialogues.text: Says he’s on the wrong plane. @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  60.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: Knows he’s on the wrong plane.

dialogues.speaker: STACY
dialogues.text: Needs to go to Rockbluff, Colorado.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: (perks up) For the Moonsong Film Festival?

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: (sighs relief) Yes . . . Thank you. If you could just open the door.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Are you, like, famous? Lincoln sees his opportunity and plays along.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: Well, I guess you might say that. Name’s Lincoln. I’m a director. Stacy and Tracy GASP, and start jockeying for position, straightening their hair, and blinking a lot. Lincoln pla into them.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: Haven’t I seen you two in something? That movie about the genius super- models who save the world? That was you, wasn’t it? They giggle modestly.

dialogues.speaker: STACY TRACY
dialogues.text: No. No.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: It wasn’t?! Well, it shoulda been! Look, I just need a small favor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stacy and Tracy escort Lincoln back out of the plane.

dialogues.speaker: STACY
dialogues.text: Your ticket’s at your new gate. @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  61.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: Thanks. I just need my bag.

dialogues.speaker: STACY
dialogues.text: Already brought up. It’s back inside there.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: Thanks, Tracy.

dialogues.speaker: STACY
dialogues.text: I'm Stacy!

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: I'm Tracy!

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: And don’t ever change. Their giggling is silenced only by the plane door closing

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one is around. Lincoln comes back in from the plane an looks around. The only bag is a large plaid suitcase with NOTE on it. Lincoln rushes to it and reads the note. INSERT NOTE: Passenger Lincoln.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: Uh, no... wrong bag. Hello? Not mine. Anyone? He looks to the window just in time to see his plane take off. As it climbs, he walks toward the window in a daze. keeps walking until - THUD. His forehead hits the glass. It doesn’t seem to pha him. He just watches the plane disappear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: En route to Denver, Lincoln sits between a fast-asleep ro teen and an overweight businessman juggling files, coffee a laptop in the cramped space. @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  62. Lincoln looks worried. Although racked with guilt, he can help but steal glances at the romantic comedy playing silently on the plane’s small movie screen.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Could this be any more ridiculous? Lincoln PERKS UP at the familiar voice, coming from the a seat in the row in front of him. So he slowly unbuckles his belt and stands on his seat, cautiously leaning forward. Peeking. Sure enough, it’s Ethan Latte, blabbing to the cute femal traveler next to him. She wears headphones, trying to enj the movie. Ethan watches without headphones, commenting loudly. She does her best to ignore him without being rud

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: And we're supposed to believe that? (leaning to her) Why buy headphones, baby? Same movie we've all seen a thousand times. She gives up, takes off the headphones and immediately ta out a book to focus on.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: I’m with you, baby. That romantic comedy nonsense just stinks. (beat) I have a film in the Moonsong Film Festival. I’m headed there now to pick up my prize. (smirks) Of course, there’1l be other films there, too. But let’s just say I like my chances. She says nothing. Lincoln listens through the long pause which doesn’t seem to bother Ethan.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: My film’s called “Zoe’s Time”. It’s about a young girl struggling to find herself. Moonsong recognized the genius of it. Thousands of films are submitted, you know, but only the best of the best are selected. It’s not like you can just show up with a videotape. Lincoln GULPS at this new, disturbing bit of information. slumps back in his chair, lost in thought - and guilt. @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  63. He takes up the camera bag, takes out the final-cut DV ta marked “In the Cage” and stares at it.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: No way, baby. Not at Moonsong. This is the big time. Amateurs and losers, stay home. Next to the camera is the Polaroid of him and Jefferson. takes it out and looks at it, troubled. Lincoln settles b in his seat, lost in thought.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Okay, status update. I’m on my way to a festival I wasn’t invited to. With a movie I won’t be able to show anyone. And my brother will soon arrive lost in another city. Okay. Could this trip get any worse?

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You know who’s overrated? The German Expressionists -- I know what you’re going to say, the emphasis on self through the medium - believe me, I’m all for that. But what did they really accomplish, artistically? The sleeping teen next to Lincoln fidgets, and his headph fall off onto his lap. Lincoln carefully unplugs them fro the teen’s music player, plugs them into his armrest, and puts them on, settling in to the movie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The giant duffle sits alone beside the baggage carousel u an “oversized bags” sign. The zipper is pulled from the inside and gives, sliding open a little. Jefferson peeks

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Where is he?

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: He’ll be here. Just shhhh!

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I have a cramp.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: Who doesn’t? @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  64.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I do! I’m sorry - was that one of those historical questions?

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: Alright the coast is clear. I’1l have a look around. Jefferson tries to get out smoothly and cautiously, but t when his foot gets stuck. He tries to kick free.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Ow. That would be me.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: Sorry. After more clumsy struggle, he frees himself, just as a buzzing ALARM SOUNDS. Jefferson freezes, thinking he’s caught, but it’s just a carousel starting up. The room suddenly fills with passen from another flight. Jefferson freezes again at the sight of the human crowd. Washington notices.

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: Never mind them. Just find Lincoln.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: (gulp) Maybe you better come along. Jefferson grabs the duffel handle. Washington sighs and sticks his hands and feet out the bottom to walk along. Jefferson walks along the rental car counters “carrying” duffel, and getting perplexed stares from people he passe They arrive at the quarter-locker area.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: Maybe we can find you some clothes and you can get out. The bag unzips. Washington gets out. Ross sticks her head

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: I’m all for that. Jefferson motions with his head toward the lockers. @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  65.

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: You want me to break the doors?

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: Do I look like I have a key? Washington smiles as he RIPS the door open. Inside is a suitcase containing a few items, including a huge, tent-l DRESS and matching floppy HAT.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: Perfect.

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: I don’t think so.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: We're not shopping here. It fits; put it on. Washington GRUNTS and pulls the dress over his head and p on the hat. Jefferson motions for him to pick up the bag, Washington just stands there.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: C'mon.

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: I - can’t.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: Look, I don’t care if you’re embarrassed. Now swallow your pride and let’s go.

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: I... can’t.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: Why not?!

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: I need you to zip me up. Jefferson suppresses a laugh and stands on the duffle to Washington’s dress. He comes down and inspects the outfit

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: It’s so last year. Are you okay with that? Ross laughs. @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  66.

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: You know what I think is funny? All this joking around after being abandoned.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: What? Lincoln did not abandon us.

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: You have a better explanation?

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: He’s obviously in trouble. Do you know what they do to anyone doing anything out of the ordinary on airplanes and airports these days?!

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: It’s a total violation of civil rights.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: He could be captured. Those people could be, at this very moment, torturing him with tiny, sharp objects!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: a human hand holding a toothpick. The hands THR down and we follow as the toothpick lands ... .» . . in a Swedish meatball on a houer d’ovre tray full meatballs. The human picks up the meatball and eats it. As the waiter moves along, we see Lincoln outside a windo peeking in at the party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lincoln at the window. He peeks around the building’s cor at the entrance. Everyone going into the party wears a festival credential badge A security guard checks badges greets guests warmly. Without a badge, Lincoln is stumped -- until he sees Etha Latte coming OUT of the party dialing his cell phone. Eth walks a comfortable distance from the building. Lincoln climbs up a tree and over above Ethan, listening. @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  67.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: (into phone) It’s a lock. Nothing but hacks here. That prize is as good as mine. Call me when you get this message. Ciao! Behind him, Lincoln jumps down - right in Ethan’s path - before Ethan turns back. Ethan is startled by this short, odd-looking man.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: Ethan Latte?

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: Yes, and you are?

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: Max Linkletter. Bigshot Productions. Got a sneak peek of your film. Don’t ask how. The thing is, you made it. I love it. We want it. And we'll pay big.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: I’m sure there will be many offers.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: Not like ours, kid. Six picture deal. Nobody gets in your way. Ever. Walk with me. We'll talk Lincoln heads away from the front door, around the buildi

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: Why not just talk inside?

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: Too many Hollywood phonies, know what I’m saying?

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: I sure do. Ethan follows him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lincoln has led Ethan to a side service/kitchen delivery entrance. Large crates and boxes are stacked around. A delivery truck with its back open idles nearby. @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  68. No one is around.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: So you have a deal for me?

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: All in good time. But first -- Lincoln jumps onto a stack of crates, making him about as tall as Ethan. He puts his arm around Ethan’s shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: -- I want you to picture something with me. . . Your name, in lights - Lincoln directs Ethan’s gaze into the night sky. While Lincoln speaks and Ethan dreams, Lincoln uses his tail to swipe Ethan’s Festival Credentials, cell phone and hotel

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: - as tall as a building! Everyone knowing what they’re coming to see. The name of the movie -- er, I mean the film, doesn’t even matter. As long as it was made by Ethan Latte.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: I like the way you think. Suddenly Ethan’s cell phone - in LINCOLN’S pocket - rings Ethan is perplexed, can’t find his phone, then notices hi badge and room key are gone, too.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: Hey! What’s going on here? who are you?!? Lincoln climbs up higher, out of reach.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: I told you. Rex Litelinker.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: You said your name was Max Linkletter.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: (busted) Well, you can never have too many names in Hollywood. Ethan climbs after him, but Lincoln easily gets down. Lin runs along the delivery dock and Ethan chases, fuming, wh suddenly the service entrance door swings open and SMACKS dead in the face. @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  69. An oblivious DELIVERY GUY walks past to his truck. The do swings closed, revealing a dizzy Ethan, who angrily stumb on toward a seemingly cornered Lincoln. Ethan lunges to TACKLE Lincoln, but the chimp deftly clim the crates, leaving Ethan to CRASH into them. Now even more groggy, Ethan looks around for Lincoln.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: Where are you, you little freak?

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Over here, you pretentious amateur. Ethan spies Lincoln standing on the edge of the loading d with truck right behind him. Enraged at the insult, a bruised and battered Ethan races him. At the last second Lincoln unlatches the truck’s bac door, and holds the strap. As the door rolls up and open, Lincoln is lifted out of harm's way. Lincoln’s tail, hanging down, holds a BOARD which SMACKS rushing Ethan right in the face. Lincoln jumps back to the dock. Practically unconscious, Ethan stands teetering on the edge of the small loading d As the delivery truck revs into gear, Lincoln swings his around so the board BONKS Ethan on the butt, knocking him into the back of the truck. The impact of Ethan landing a the truck pulling away causes the door to tumble down shu Lincoln tosses the board, which LOCKS the truck door, jus the truck pulls away. Satisfied, Lincoln nods and turns away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lincoln enters showing Ethan’s credentials. He’s fixed hi own picture and name to the badge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lincoln soaks up the scene, but only gets odd stares from beautiful, wealthy Hollywood crowd. He takes out Ethan's phone and PRETENDS to talk on it - just loud enough so th around him can hear. @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  70.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: I’m telling you, they got my film title wrong. I spent all this time and money making “Zooing Time” and it shows up in the program as “Zoey's Time.” A RECEPTION MAN and WOMAN nearby lean in, listening.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: I couldn't believe it.... I’m not kidding. Some festival this turned out to be. I kept telling them: “It’s not Zoey’s Time. It’s “Zooing Time...” He looks around to ensure he’s being listened to.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: --. It’s not “Zoey’s Time”. It’s Zooing Time.” I don’t know how much clearer I can be.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTION MAN
dialogues.text: (whispers) Zooing Time? The woman raises her eyebrows in interest then whispers i the ear of another woman nearby. That woman takes out her program and together they look and point.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: As far as I’m concerned this festival's reputation is at stake. MONTAGE of guests whispering and pointing as the news spr throughout the party. Lincoln looks around triumphantly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jefferson and Washington (in his dress and hat, carrying large purse) stand with coffees at the cream and sugar counter. Ross pokes her head out of Washington's purse.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: That smells good. Did you get me one? By way of answer, Washington pushes her head back in. @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  71. They watch another patron, COFFEE GUY approach, dump coff into the trash and pour cream in. Shrugging to each other Jefferson and Washington do the same.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: Excuse me, we’re trying to get to the Moonsong Film Festival.

dialogues.speaker: COFFEE GUY
dialogues.text: First thing is get back on a plane.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: Pardon?

dialogues.speaker: COFFEE GUY
dialogues.text: Festival’s in Colorado. (thinks ) Or you could take a bus. A lot cheaper. Good luck! The Coffee Guy walks away, sipping carefully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jefferson and Washington come out into the bustle of honk cars and waiting cabs. Soliciting CABBIES noticeably avoi the freakish guy and huge, hairy lady.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: We need a place to lay low. Maybe we stay here.

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: I don’t exactly feel welcome. Ross pokes her head out.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: Hey, look! She points to a cab with an LA ZOO poster ad on top. Jefferson looks to Washington, who shrugs in agreement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The DRIVER sleeps at the wheel. Jefferson knocks on the h open window, startling him awake.

dialogues.speaker: CAB DRIVER
dialogues.text: What?! I can wait here. Huh? Who are you? @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  72.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: Can you take us to the zoo?

dialogues.speaker: CAB DRIVER
dialogues.text: I’m on break. Any cab can take you to the zoo! Suddenly Washington leans into frame, looking menacing. T driver reacts with fear.

dialogues.speaker: CAB DRIVER
dialogues.text: Okay-okay. Yeah, sure. Get in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Washington and Ross are just inside a wooded area, at the far, secluded end of the lot. They are keeping hidden, peeking toward the zoo’s front gate, where they see the l employee car drive away, leaving the place dark.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: How long have we been here?

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: Too long. Suddenly Jefferson jumps down from a tree BEHIND them.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: Hey. They turn, startled.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: What? -- We thought you were in there.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: I was. The coast is clear. C’mon.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: You got us room and board?

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: Even better. I got a job.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: (excited) What?!?

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: We'll have money for bus tickets by morning. @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  73. Washington still stares at the zoo entrance, lost in thou

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: Maybe this was a mistake.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: What are you talking about? Good night’s sleep. Big breakfast ...

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: (snaps out of it) Huh? What? What did you say?

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: C’mon. We got a zoo to clean. They head to the gate. Washington hesitates, then follows

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No people. Jefferson leads a TEAM of chimps cleaning up t grounds. They all work quickly and efficiently, making th whole place spotless. Ross approaches Jefferson.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: I'm impressed.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: Lincoln’s not the only charming, influential one in the family.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: That's true... What do you think happened to him?

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: Some kind of mix up. I don’t know. Where’s Washington?

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: Turned in early. He’s been acting weird since we got here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Washington walks around receiving stares from the other gorillas. He too, looks them over, but in a different way is looking for someone. @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  74. Someone he doesn’t find, so he sits off in a corner by himself and lets go a sigh as heavy as he is.

dialogues.speaker: PATTY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Of all the gorilla cages in all the zoos in this crazy world... Washington perks up at the sound of her familiar, gentle, worldly voice. He speaks without turning around as we see PATTY, a female gorilla emerge from the shadows behind hi

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: I knew you'd be here.

dialogues.speaker: PATTY
dialogues.text: And I knew you’d come back one day. Aren't we the smart ones? We shoulda been chimps. Washington smiles.

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: How have you been, Patty?

dialogues.speaker: PATTY
dialogues.text: Good. . . I guess. She comes to him and they sit face to face, looking for w was once there but is now distant, if not altogether lost

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: They treat you well here?

dialogues.speaker: PATTY
dialogues.text: Of course. You?

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: It’s been a struggle.

dialogues.speaker: PATTY
dialogues.text: Why does that not surprise me?

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: PATTY
dialogues.text: You always made everything harder than it was. Work. Us. From the day we met to the day you left. Washington is surprised to hear it phrased that way. @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  75.

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: The day I_ left? You act like I had a choice.

dialogues.speaker: PATTY
dialogues.text: I guess not.

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: (angering a bit) You guess? Being put in a cage is one thing. But when they put your cage on a truck and drive out of town, it’s not like ...

dialogues.speaker: PATTY
dialogues.text: Ever wonder why you were put on that truck?

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: (angered) Because I wasn’t needed anymore--

dialogues.speaker: PATTY
dialogues.text: -- Because you were difficult! Washington GRUNTS. He doesn’t want to hear that.

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: It was a difficult time.

dialogues.speaker: PATTY
dialogues.text: It was almost two days before I even knew you were gone. Do you know how hard that was?

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: Yes! Actually, I know exactly how hard that was! It was just as hard as finding a way back to you. But I did it! Now it seems I came all the way back so we could argue.

dialogues.speaker: PATTY
dialogues.text: I don’t know why you came back.

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: (defeated) To see you. I just wanted to see you.

dialogues.speaker: PATTY
dialogues.text: What for?

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: Because I was tired of not seeing you. @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  76. They turn to each other. She puts her head on his shoulde

dialogues.speaker: PATTY
dialogues.text: I know it wasn’t your fault.

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: It’s good . . . to see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A quaint but modern theater. Lincoln stands by a sign tha reads “Tonight’s Screening: Zoey's Zooing Time”. Lincoln greets excited guests as they file in.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: Good to see you . . . Good to see you .. . Thanks for coming. . Welcome . . . Good to see you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Packed house waits in anticipation as Zooing Time begins. Lincoln stands in the back, anxious. Onscreen is the series of close-ups of cage bars and lock

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It looks harmless enough from the outside, but don’t be fooled. Life in a zoo is no different than life in prison. Except for one thing. Those in prison, it can be assumed, have committed some crime. The shot switches to the ostrich, looking helpless and hopeless.

dialogues.speaker: OSTRICH
dialogues.text: I never did anything wrong. The Moonsong audience BURSTS OUT LAUGHING. Lincoln freezes in shock as the movie continues.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (from the movie) So why is it that we are forced to live in these cages, unable to roam free as we are meant to. @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  77. DISSOLVING MONTAGE of the audience cracking up, and Linco rising panic. We hear snippets of animals talking from th screen; each line spoken gets a roaring laugh.

dialogues.speaker: AUDIENCE MEMBER 1
dialogues.text: How do they do that?

dialogues.speaker: AUDIENCE MEMBER 2
dialogues.text: The animals are chewing gum. Then they dub in the actors’ voices. Brilliant, isn’t it?

dialogues.speaker: AUDIENCE MEMBER 1
dialogues.text: Hilarious! More laughter as we see Lincoln, trying desperately to se the bright side. At least they like it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lincoln is MOBBED by congratulatory festival-goers. Lost brother aside, he can’t help but be swept up in the attention. Press microphones are thrust at him.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: What’s next for you, Lincoln?

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: I'd just like to finish the festival, see where we are and go from there.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER 2, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You think Hollywood's ready for you?

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: We’1ll soon find out, won't we? Crowd laughter.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER 3, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hey, Lincoln! Where’d you get the idea for your movie? Lincoln gulps, suddenly brought back to reality.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: Uh, well. Actually my brother had a lot to do with it. @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  78.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER 2
dialogues.text: He must be one funny guy! The crowd laughs in agreement.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: No, he’s not. I mean, he is, but it’s just that --

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER 2, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Where is that wacky brother of yours, anyway?

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: I don’t... I mean I’m not sure, exactly . On Lincoln’s saddened face we...

dialogues.speaker: LA ZOO GROUNDS
dialogues.text: Jefferson walking along, ELATED. He climbs up a bench and jumps over the back as he heads past an arrow sign that reads: GORILLAS. At the gorilla cage, Jefferson looks in and sees Washingt in an intimate cuddle with Patty. His eyes widen in surpr

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: A-hem. Washington and Patty look up.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: I have some great news.

dialogues.speaker: PATTY
dialogues.text: (sees shaved Jefferson) Goodness! What happened to you?

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: (to Patty) It’s a long story. (to Jefferson) What is it?

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: Sorry to -ahem - interrupt. I already made enough money for one bus ticket. If I go in the bag, we can leave tonight. @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  79.

dialogues.speaker: PATTY
dialogues.text: A bus ticket?!

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: You two . . . know each other?

dialogues.speaker: PATTY
dialogues.text: So I guess I wasn’t the purpose of this trip.

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: You were the purpose of my trip. Jefferson has his own reasons for being here.

dialogues.speaker: PATTY
dialogues.text: What reasons?

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: (confused) It’s about a movie we made. Patty looks surprised. Washington winces.

dialogues.speaker: PATTY
dialogues.text: (to Washington) You made another movie? Now it’s Jefferson who is surprised.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: Another movie? Patty laughs.

dialogues.speaker: PATTY
dialogues.text: (to Washington) He doesn’t know? I should have guessed. Mr. Secret. (to Jefferson) Your friend here was a movie star.

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: Patty, don’t.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: A what?!?!?

dialogues.speaker: PATTY
dialogues.text: It was years ago, but he was the most sought-after gorilla in the business. You made - what? - five pictures? @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  80. Washington sighs. He’s not going to avoid this talk, as m as he’d like to.

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: Six.

dialogues.speaker: PATTY
dialogues.text: (to Jefferson) Let’s see, there was Jungle Escape, Return to the Jungle, Jungle Hunters, Jungle Dawn, Night of the Living Jungle...

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: Let’s not forget my comedy... Washington leaves them.

dialogues.speaker: PATTY
dialogues.text: Oh yeah. Jungle Bungle. Ever heard of those? Jefferson nods enthusiastically, but after only a second, shifts to shaking his head no.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: But my brother would know them! He’s the movie expert. He’s at the Moonsong Film Festival right now, with our documentary...

dialogues.speaker: PATTY
dialogues.text: Moonsong . . . impressive. Jefferson looks in the direction Washington went. Patty f sorry to have brought it up that way.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: I better...

dialogues.speaker: PATTY
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: EXT LA ZOO GRASSY HILL
dialogues.text: Washington sits by himself, stargazing. He sighs. Jefferson appears at the bottom of the hill.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: Mind if I come up? @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  81.

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: I guess not. Jefferson ascends and sits down next to the big gorilla.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: Doesn't seem like anything to be ashamed of. Being in movies, I mean.

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: I’m not ashamed. I loved that work. (pause) And I admire your passion. I once had passion like you do. For the movies. For Patty.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: I woke up one morning and instead of being taken to work, I was taken to the Chicago zoo.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: Wow. I’m sorry. (thinks ) That’s the story we should have told in the movie. No response. Jefferson lets out a nervous laugh.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: Next time. They sit quietly for a few moments.

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: Next time. Jefferson smiles.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: I take it you won’t be coming to Colorado with us. Washington just shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: You take care of yourself. And your friend, too. She must be pretty special. @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  82.

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: She is. . . Same for you and Ross.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: Huh? Me? Ross? We’re not - together.

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: Whatever you say. Jefferson stands.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: So I guess I’1ll see you around?

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: I can’t imagine how. Jefferson shrugs agreement, and Washington holds out his massive hand to shake. Jefferson shakes it.

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: I’1ll see you around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tired Jefferson sits by the window looking out and the sparse highway traffic. A large BACKPACK sits in the empt seat next to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON elevator door as it opens, revealing Lincoln. As steps out a BELLHOP who was waiting gets on.

dialogues.speaker: BELLHOP
dialogues.text: You’re the man! Lincoln smiles and as the elevator door closes and Lincol walks away toward his room...

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: (to himself) Yes, that was the whole shaving, tricky plan part of it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Expensive room. Lincoln comes in and is surprised to find gifts of all kinds: flowers, champagne, fruit, everything up all around the room. @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  83. He spots the phone blinking and pushes the message button

dialogues.speaker: PHONE VOICE
dialogues.text: You have thirty-one messages. Lincoln picks up the phone, then stops himself.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: Nah. Let ‘em wait. I’m the man. He hangs up and goes into the bathroom. A moment later we hear Ethan’s electric razor turn on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jefferson sleeps uncomfortably in his seat, his head pres against the window. Ross’ head now sticks out of the back and she sleeps leaning on his arm.

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE TO
dialogues.text: INT. LINCOLN’S HOTEL ROOM - SIMULTANEOUS Lincoln sleeps blissfully in his 5-Star bed, wearing silk pajamas and a hotel eye shade. A KNOCK at the door wakes him up. He listens. Another KNO

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (from hallway) Room Service. Breakfast.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: (groggy) I didn’t order anything.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (from hallway) Compliments of one of the studios, Mr. Lincoln. Lincoln smiles, gets up and opens the door, revealing the BACK of Ethan, dressed as room service waiter.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: Thanks. Just bring it on in. Lincoln moves aside as Ethan BACKS in pulling the breakfa cart, keeping his face hidden. Lincoln closes the door an turns to see -- @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  84. ETHAN! Back for revenge.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: Gotcha! Lincoln jumps for the door, but Ethan DIVES across the breakfast cart, blocking him. Lincoln runs to the bed. Ethan follows in chase and dives again, but Lincoln evades and Ethan crashes into the nightstand. Lincoln heads into the bathroom, but before he can shut t door, Ethan shoves his foot in. Ethan crashes in and slam the door. We HEAR the crashing fight in the bathroom for a few mome and then it suddenly STOPS.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (disgusted) What did you do to my razor?!?! The crashing fight continues, ending with the ringing THU of Ethan falling (presumably headfirst) into the tub. A moment later the shower turns on. Lincoln rushes out into the room, wedges a chair under th bathroom doorknob, and quickly half-dresses. Grabbing the rest of his clothes - and the video camera - he runs out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lincoln, now fully dressed, stands alone, the camera poin at himself. POV CAMERA VIEWFINDER. Lincoln’s close-up, slightly off-center face.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: I’ve got good news and bad news. The good news is: Everyone loved the movie. It’s called Zooing Time now. I’1ll explain later. The awards are tonight. I think we could actually win! Now for the bad news: First, I’m being chased by a guy who pretty much wants to kill me. Again, I'll explain later. More importantly, though, everyone thinks our movie is a comedy. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  85. LINCOLN (cont'd) No one took it seriously - But we still might win! The elevator opens in the lobby and Lincoln rushes out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lincoln nearly crashes into the desk. He puts the camera his room key card down.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: Hi!

dialogues.speaker: CONCIERGE
dialogues.text: Ah, good morning Mr. Lincoln. What can I do --?

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: -- If you see my brother. My, uh, twin brother. Give him this camera and my room key. Got it?

dialogues.speaker: CONCIERGE
dialogues.text: But of course. Happy to -- The elevator DINGS and opens. A soaking wet Ethan emerges

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: -- Gotta go. Lincoln runs out the front door. Ethan follows, slipping his wet shoes and causing a ruckus as he passes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lincoln looks frantically for help, but there is none. Th he sees a cab pulling up and beckons it to hurry.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: C’mon! C’mon! But it suddenly stops far down the curb.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: No! @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  86.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jefferson sits in the back seat. Ross pokes her head out the backpack.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: Maybe we should just get out here. I don’t want to cause a scene at the front door.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: Are you sure?

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: Just until we know what’s going on. I mean, you probably need some sort of ID badge or something to even get in.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: Well I guess so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fed up, Lincoln starts to run toward the cab, when sudden he is SNATCHED UP by Ethan and thrown into the back of a black SUV. Ethan jumps into the driver seat and speeds of nearly hitting Jefferson as he gets out of the cab.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: Whoa - maniac! Jefferson shakes his head and puts the backpack on. On his way to the front door, he is surprised by all the people smiling and waving to him. The doorman rushes to g the door for him.

dialogues.speaker: DOORMAN
dialogues.text: Good morning, Mr. Lincoln.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: Oh, I’m not -- Ross’ hand shoots out of the backpack and BONKS Jefferson the back of the head.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: Good morning. He hurries inside. @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  87.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jefferson is awestruck by the opulence.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: Holy wow. Ross pokes her head out.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: You mean holy c -- (notices) -- wow!!! They stare wide-eyed, Jefferson slowly turns, giving them 360-view of the ornate, lavish room. He finishes the turn and stands face to face with the concierge. Ross and Franklin duck down.

dialogues.speaker: CONCIERGE
dialogues.text: You must be Mr. Lincoln’s brother.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: Yes! How did you know?

dialogues.speaker: CONCIERGE
dialogues.text: Lucky guess. He asked me to give these to you. The concierge hands Jefferson the camera and room key car and leaves him. Jefferson hands the camera over his shoul Ross takes it and immediately begins filming the room.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: The guys back home are never gonna believe this.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I think they will. He looks back and sees she’s filming.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: Ah. Good idea. - (points) Get that thing over there! She turns the camera where he points. After a moment he l down at the room key card. ROOM 402. @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  88.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON the door for room 402. Jefferson puts the key card in and is rewarded with a lit green light and BEEP. As Ross looks over his shoulders, h opens the door to find ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is RANSACKED from the recent struggle. Jefferson puts the backpack down and Ross climbs out.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: This is not good.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: Hang on. We don’t know exactly what happened here. Let’s focus on what we do know. We do know that whatever happened here . .

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: ...Wasn’t good.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: Lincoln would have left a message.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: Doesn’t look like he had time.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: He would have found a way. I know it. Look around. They look through the mess for any sign. Jefferson absent mindedly picks up the camera and taps it to his temple.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: Think, think, think. If you were Lincoln, how would you try to contact us?

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: Stage a scene and film it.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: (laughs ) Yeah, right. (eureka! ) Yeah! Right! Of course! @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  89. He frantically rewinds the tape inside and pushes play. T huddle around the viewfinder and are relieved to see the close-up of Lincoln in the elevator.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: (from camera) I’ve got good news and bad news. The good news is: Everyone loved the movie. It’s called Zooing Time now. I’1ll explain later. The awards are tonight. I think we could actually win! Now for the bad news: First, I’m being chased by a guy who pretty much wants to kill me. Again, I'll explain later. More importantly, though, everyone thinks our movie is ---

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly the screen cuts to the hotel lobby, the footage just shot downstairs. Jefferson and Ross look at each other in a panic.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: Too much bad news is never good.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: (from camera) The guys back home are never gonna believe we were here.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: (from camera) I think they will.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: (from camera) Ah. Good idea. Get that over there! Jefferson shuts it off.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: What are we gonna do --?? Suddenly there is a rattle and the KEY BEEP at the door. two of them dive under the bed just as Ethan returns. They can only see his trendy ORANGE TIP shoes, and have n idea who he is - only that he can lead them to Lincoln. Ethan sits on the bed and dials the bedside table phone. @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  90.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: Hey, it’s me. That little freak who railroaded me and stole my screening spot? Let’s just say he won't be bothering me any more. Jefferson and Ross suppress a gasp.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: What? No, I didn’t throw him in a river with cement shoes! I’m at a film festival! I’m not in a film! Jefferson and Ross sigh relief.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: I’m going to the awards show tonight and I’m gonna fix this mess! I’1ll talk to you later. Ethan hangs up, quickly stands and leaves. The two monkey try to get a look at his face, but can’t.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: Follow him! They run for the door and as Jefferson reaches for the doorknob, it BEEPS again and TURNS from the outside. Ross quickly stands on Jefferson’s shoulders behind the opening door. Ethan barges back in. The door CRUNCHES against Jefferson Ross. Ethan heads toward his sunglasses, which he left on bedside table. As he walks over to them, the door swings closed revealing the monkeys to Ethan's back. Jefferson’s arms are full holding Ross, so at the last second, he uses his tail to grab the doorknob - just befo it closes - and quickly pull it back open to cover them - just as Ethan turns back around. Ethan walks quickly out, grabbing the doorknob and slammi it shut behind him. Unfortunately, Jefferson’s tail is still wrapped around t knob on the inside, so Ethan’s tug pulls Jefferson down, toppling both of them. Ross lands on her head and is knocked out cold. Jefferson sneaks out after Ethan. @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  gl. A moment later he returns, having noticed Ross wasn’t wit him.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: Ross? Ross! Are you okay? He gently shakes her and she comes to.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: Huh? Where is he? Did you get a look at him?

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: No, he got on the elevator.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: He said he’s going to the awards show. We’ll catch him there.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: How will we know who he is? How will we get in?

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: (thinks ) You go - as Lincoln.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: No, I can’t. The crowd - What if we win? I’ll have to give a speech.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: That’ll be perfect! Everyone will be cheering - except our guy. Take that stage and you can I-D him!

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: Can’t we just sneak in and look for orange-tip shoes? Ross just looks at him, letting him realize on his own ho dumb an idea that is.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: It could be our only chance to find Lincoln. Plus, if you do win, do you realize what that means?

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: That I'll have to speak in front of hundreds of people. @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  92.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: It means your movie was accepted by humans. Everything you've been working for . . . the cause. . It’s all a success. You did it.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: (thinks ) I don’t know... Suddenly Ross KISSES him. He’s shocked, but he likes it.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: You can do this. I believe in you. Dazed, Jefferson goes into the bathroom and shuts the doo moment later, we hear Ethan’s razor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The large room is empty except for Jefferson - NOW BALD a in a TUX -- paces nervously by the concession counter. We hear the DIN of applause in the theater. The awards show underway.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: You can do this. You can do this. INT. THEATER — SIMULTANEOUS High above the stage, hidden in the lighting fixtures, si Ross. She searches the audience.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: I hope he can do this. Onstage, a PRESENTER stands at the podium.

dialogues.speaker: PRESENTER
dialogues.text: And the Audience Selection Award for the Best Picture goes to ... Zooing Time by Lincoln! The crowd erupts in applause, then looks around. The presenter is left on stage holding the award. Above, Ross looks around, disappointed. @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  93.

dialogues.speaker: PRESENTER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Uh, I guess Lincoln couldn’t make it tonight.

dialogues.speaker: PRESENTER
dialogues.text: - I'd like to accept this award on his behalf, and --

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: -- Wait! I’m here! Jefferson stands back of the theater. The crowd erupts ag in applause as they turn to see him. Jefferson walks all the way to the stage, to rapturous applause. Strangers reach out to shake his hand. As nervo as he is, he can’t help feeling proud. Maybe Ross was rig Maybe the cause has succeeded. FROM THE RAFTERS Ross watches him, beaming with pride. Onstage, Jefferson takes the award, and stares at the microphone. The applause die down and Jefferson moves no closer to the podium. The presenter lowers the mic for Jefferson, then moves as and holds out his hand, coaxing Jefferson to speak. Jefferson slinks up to the podium and arrives just in tim have his nervous GULP amplified throughout the theater. Everyone laughs.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: I'm... I’m not very good at this. Speaking in front of people, I’m afraid. Thank you, so much for this honor. I’m glad you liked In the Cage -- uh, I mean, Zooing Time. The audience laughs and claps.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: It’s a serious issue we address in the movie, and I hope that now that you've seen the other side, we can begin to work toward real change. The audience is SILENT. Then one person’s laughter incite cheering, clapping laugh riot. It seems only the cheers a applause register with Jefferson. @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  94.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: We can live together in peace! We can! We can! We can! RIOTOUS LAUGHTER. Some audience members even take up the Can!” chant - just for laughs. Jefferson raises the award in his fist triumphantly and receives another CHEER. IN THE RAFTERS: Suddenly Ross sees Ethan, motionless with look of angry bewilderment on his face. Jefferson bounds off the stage toward the wings, but can’ help turning back for one more victory stance - this time both hands raised high. The crowd goes berserk. Ross watches Ethan push toward the aisle and walk quickly the back of the theater. Ross climbs along the ceiling fixtures, directly over him. His orange-tip shoes are clearly visible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Several ACTIVISTS from the group HAHA (HUMAN AGAINST HURT ANIMALS) stand in protest, carrying signs that read STOP ANIMAL EXPLOITATION!; CAGES ARE NOT FUNNY!; and a circled red-slashed words ZOOING TIME. Jefferson comes out, hounded by reporters. Ethan approach but can’t get near him through the crowd. Ross stays hidden, trying to get Jefferson's attention. Jefferson sees the protest group and go right to them.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: Thank you. Thank you so much for coming! People are cracking up at what they see as “Lincoln's” audacity. The activists BOO Jefferson.

dialogues.speaker: ACTIVIST 1
dialogues.text: How could you?!?

dialogues.speaker: ACTIVIST 2
dialogues.text: You should be ashamed of yourself! Jefferson stops and looks behind himself, confused. @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  95.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: ACTIVIST 1
dialogues.text: Making fun of poor, helpless zoo animals. You’re not funny!

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: Making fun -- huh?

dialogues.speaker: ACTIVIST 2
dialogues.text: Yeah, you’re the animal.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: (surprised) How did you --? Look, that has nothing to do with it. Suddenly, Jefferson sees Ross in a tree above the protest She frantically points to Ethan heading toward his car.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: Look, I gotta go. You got it all wrong. I’m on your side. More BOOS from the activists as Jefferson rushes off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A helmeted, goggled Jefferson does his best to steer a VE Ahead of them are the taillights of Ethan’s black SUV. Jefferson keeps a safe distance as Ethan pulls into the d parking lot of THE SILVER SCREEN ROADSIDE MOTEL.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lincoln is tied to a chair in the middle of the sparse, d room. One lamp is lit. He doesn’t seem phased as he watches a classic black-and- white movie on the meager TV. When he hears Ethan’s car pull up outside and the car doo open and close, he quickly uses his tail on the remote to turn off the TV. As Ethan unlocks the room door and rushes in, Lincoln ado a much more anguished look on his face. @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  96. Ethan is SHOCKED to see Lincoln still there.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: How?!?!? How did you do it?!

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: (thinks ) The remote was right there on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: Don’t play games with me! How did you get to that ceremony?! And how did you get back here and tie yourself up?!?!

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: What? Ethan starts frantically searching the room.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: Where is it?! Where did you hide the Award?!? It’s mine!

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: What awar-- ? .... We won?

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: You didn’t win! You stole that award! From me! I was supposed to

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: win!

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: (to himself) We won.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: Where is it?!?!? Ethan lunges for the defenseless Lincoln, but there is a KNOCK at the door. Ethan stops and answers it. No one is there. As he leans out and checks left and righ Jefferson slides the window open, climbs into the room an tiptoes to the door, PUSHING it shut and PUSHING Ethan ou Jefferson runs to Lincoln, untying him.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: Are you alright?

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: We won? @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  97.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: They thought it was a joke.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: I know. Sorry about that. Didn’t you get my message?

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: Uh.... yeah. Most of it.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: But we won?

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: Yeah. We won. Now how do we get out of here?

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: I have a plan. As Lincoln is freed, the door is unlocked and opened. Eth comes back in and is dumbstruck by Lincoln's double.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: You... It can’t be ... Two of you? Just then, a crash by the window as Ross climbs in.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: I don’t see him. Ethan is stunned silent at the sight of the talking monke She SEES Ethan and realizes she just spoke in front of hi

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: (monkey sounds) Ooh-ooh-ahh-ahh.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: This isn’t happening. This can’t be happening!

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: Get him! The three monkeys CHARGE at Ethan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lincoln, Jefferson and Ross are now ALL tied to chairs. E paces back and forth, scheming. @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  98.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: Get him? That was your big plan?

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: It could've worked.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: This isn’t a movie. This is real life.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: Quiet, you two. Okay, here’s the thing. You will give me my award. I will send the Moonsong officials - and the police - here and you will explain to them what you did to me. Suddenly there is a knock at the door.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: Go away! I’m busy!

dialogues.speaker: MALE VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (from outside) Room Service! Ethan looks confused. Lincoln lights up a bit.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: I was hungry.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: (fuming) You called -- ? Ethan angrily opens the door. As soon as he does -- -- a GIANT GORILLA ARM thrusts in and grabs him by the throat, lifting him off of the ground, causing his shoes fall off. Washington enters, looking meaner than King Kong.

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: Is there a problem here? Ethan turns even WHITER with fear. He gasps for breath.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: You're . . . talking! How? Please...please .... I’1l do anything....just don’t hurt me... Washington lifts him higher, then ROARS at the top of his lungs, causing Ethan to FAINT from fear. @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  99. He tosses Ethan on the bed and unties his friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lincoln. Jefferson , Ross and Washington get in Ethan’s S Washington is in the driver's seat.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: You sure you can drive this thing?

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: I take it you never saw Night of the Living Jungle. Lincoln suddenly realizes.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: Wait. That was you? Washington looks back toward the motel.

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: You coming? Patty comes out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: PATTY
dialogues.text: Just tidying up a bit. Quite a mess in there. As she joins them, Lincoln looks confused.

dialogues.speaker: PATTY
dialogues.text: I’m Patty. Nice to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: Likewise. They pile into the car and drive off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The old gang is back again, this time listening to Washin and Patty telling stories of their old Hollywood days. Mo enraptured is Lincoln, who sits front and center. Ross and Jefferson, clearly a couple, holding hands, also look on. Franklin approaches them.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: Hey, Fraklin. Did you miss me? @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  Jefferson 100.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Did you go somewhere?

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: Very funny. What have you been up to?

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE SPIDER MONKEYS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Franklin! C’mon! and Ross look to see two cute, teeny-bopper spider monkeys sitting in the low branches of a tree. They look to Franklin.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN
dialogues.text: Nothin’ much. Catch you later. He leaves. Ross and Jefferson laugh and shake their heads They turn Jefferson The crowd The crowd their attention back to the crowd - but not before sneaks a couple of glances back at the girls.

dialogues.speaker: PATTY
dialogues.text: Tell them about the time the star got stuck in his trailer.

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: Oh, they don’t want to hear that again.... BEGS him.

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON
dialogues.text: I have a better idea. Why don’t we hear from Lincoln, who had a real Hollywood adventure. Danger, action, intrigue... (to Lincoln) Whaddya say? encourages him, so Lincoln takes center stage.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: There I was . . . tied to a chair with no way out. My captor on his way back... Ross and Jefferson laugh and shake their heads.

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE TO
dialogues.text: @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  101.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s winter now, but the same crowd has gathered again to hear the latest version of the story from Lincoln.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN
dialogues.text: All I had to do was get to that lamp, break it open and use the electrical current to burn through the ropes... Jefferson’s eyes go wide at this latest embellishment. He motions to Ross that maybe they should take a walk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ross and Jefferson walk arm in arm, enjoying the silence of course, each other’s company.

dialogues.speaker: CHEETAH, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Pssssst! They stop walking and are surprised to see a strange CHEE outside the zoo fence.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: Can I help you?

dialogues.speaker: CHEETAH
dialogues.text: Are you Lincoln?

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: No, Lincoln is my brother.

dialogues.speaker: CHEETAH
dialogues.text: He made Zooing Time?

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: Actually, Jefferson here is the mastermind behind Zooing Time.

dialogues.speaker: CHEETAH
dialogues.text: Oh, I guess I came to meet you, then.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: That's very nice -- huh? Wait a minute. Where are you from?

dialogues.speaker: CHEETAH
dialogues.text: San Diego. @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  102.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: How did you see Zooing Time?

dialogues.speaker: CHEETAH
dialogues.text: Are you kidding? Everyone’s seen it.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: Everyone?

dialogues.speaker: CHEETAH
dialogues.text: Sure. There are bootleg copies in every zoo in the country. Probably the world by now.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: Are you serious?

dialogues.speaker: CHEETAH
dialogues.text: Yeah. Everyone wants to meet you. I’m just the fastest.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: Yes, cheetahs are fast - and proud of it. We know.

dialogues.speaker: CHEETAH
dialogues.text: No, I mean. I just ran ahead. The cheetah motions behind him with his head. Jefferson a Ross look. At first they see only the dark night, but as their eyes adjust to the hillside, they see a PILGRIMAGE of zoo anim making their way toward the fence. There are hundreds, ma thousands of silhouettes getting closer and closer. Jefferson is choked up almost to tears.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: Looks like the cause is alive and well. Jefferson nods.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: You gonna be able to talk to all of them?

dialogues.speaker: JEFFERSON
dialogues.text: I think so. Yeah. @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  103.

dialogues.speaker: OVER END CREDITS
dialogues.text: The film geek security guard watches the end credits of y another DVD. He hits a button on the remote and the DVD s off, switching the screen to regular TV. Onscreen is a cheesy entertainment “reporter”. Emblazoned the lower right corner of the screen is a logo for BIZ BU

dialogues.speaker: BIZ BUZZ GUY
dialogues.text: I'm here following up on another Lincoln sighting. No, not the sixteenth President of the United States, we’re talking about the missing filmmaker. You may recall last year Biz Buzz brought you the exclusive story about the guy who came out of nowhere, took the top prize at the Moonsong Film Festival, and then vanished. Just like that. Since then the rumors have been flying, and people are coming from all over the world, claiming to have seen the cinematic genius. Like the folks here in this small California town, who say Lincoln himself came into their diner just two nights ago. I talked to them earlier. An old man - short order cook.

dialogues.speaker: OLD MAN
dialogues.text: I don’t read those celebrity movie magazines. Wife does, but I don’t. He had the turkey club. That much I know. An old woman - cashier.

dialogues.speaker: OLD WOMAN
dialogues.text: It was him alright. I recognized him from the pictures on TV, but I didn’t want to let him know that I knew what I knew. . . about him being him, I mean. A middle-aged man - diner patron.

dialogues.speaker: DINER PATRON
dialogues.text: He was hinting that he worked for the government. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  104. DINER PATRON (cont'd) I figured that’s why he had to drop out of the movie scene. Can’t be covert and famous, right? . . . Too bad, too. Real funny movie that guy made. A waiter we see from the back brings the man his food.

dialogues.speaker: BIZ BUZZ GUY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: How about you, sir, did you see him. Biz Buzz camera keeps the waiter in frame as he turns aro It's ETHAN LATTE, looking like a defeated mess.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: See who? What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: BIZ BUZZ GUY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Lincoln, the missing genius filmmaker. Ethan FREAKS OUT and runs into the kitchen, breaking thin along the way. Biz Buzz shot goes back to Biz Buzz guy outside the diner

dialogues.speaker: BIZ BUZZ GUY
dialogues.text: As you can see, it’s a very emotional story. Seems like every time we dig for answers, all we uncover is more questions. Now allegations that Lincoln is actually a government agent. Did he disappear so suddenly to protect his identity? Was he called on a top secret mission? Or was it something else? Was his disappearance by choice at all? We talked to a former government agent who declined to be shown on camera. Close-up of shadowy figure.

dialogues.speaker: GOVT AGENT
dialogues.text: If he is an agent, and I’m not at liberty to say if he is or not - and he made a movie, came into the spotlight like that, there’d be trouble. That I can tell you. The film geek zoo security guard shuts off the TV.

dialogues.speaker: END
dialogues.text: @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055  105. @Michaal Mallin / wea #11NR055
